H0.text: Most butterflies did not survive because they emerged in April during the unusually low snowpack of 1989 in portions of the Sierra Nevada Mountains, before flowers appeared in May.

H1.text: Most butterflies reproduced earlier was the most likely result of the early emergence of Edith's checkerspot butterflies in April in 1989, when unusually low snowpack in portions of the Sierra Nevada Mountains caused flowers to appear only in May.

H2.text: Most butterflies switched to other food sources in 1989 after unusually low snowpack in portions of the Sierra Nevada Mountains caused a widespread April emergence of Edith's checkerspot butterflies, when flowers do not appear until May.

H3.text: Most butterflies adapted to the new environment as a result of the early April emergence in 1989’s unusually low snowpack in portions of the Sierra Nevada Mountains, where flowers did not appear until May.

A4.text: Flowers appeared in May in portions of the Sierra Nevada Mountains in 1989.

A5.text: Edith's checkerspot butterflies emerged in April in 1989 in portions of the Sierra Nevada Mountains.
